study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy as a second-line treatment for chronic tendon injuries.
results_summary: The study found that Low-Level Laser Therapy has less evidence of effectiveness compared to first-line treatments like eccentric exercise but may be a reasonable alternative for patients with persistent pain despite rehabilitative exercise.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic tendon injuries, including Achilles tendinopathy and patellar tendon injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing acute and chronic neck pain, measured by the visual analog scale (VAS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis of five trials on cervical myofascial pain syndrome (CMPS) showed a mean improvement in VAS scores with LLLT, but the evidence was inconclusive due to significant heterogeneity and potential bias. The benefit, while statistically significant, did not meet the threshold for minimally important clinical difference.
population_specificity: Patients with cervical myofascial pain syndrome (CMPS) and other neck pain conditions (443 patients across eight randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for managing oral lichen planus (OLP) unresponsive to standard topical therapy.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in lesion size and reported pain, with no detailed complications or side effects observed. LLLT was suggested as a viable treatment option for unresponsive symptomatic OLP.
population_specificity: 30 patients with oral lichen planus (OLP) unresponsive to standard topical therapy.
effective_dosage: 980-nm gallium-aluminum-arsenide (GaAIAs) diode laser (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on Bell's palsy recovery.
results_summary: Both HILT and LLLT significantly improved Bell's palsy recovery, with HILT showing slightly greater effectiveness than LLLT. The study used FDI and HBS scales to measure improvements at 3 and 6 weeks post-treatment.
population_specificity: 48 patients with Bell's palsy, mean age 43 ± 9.8 years.
effective_dosage: Laser treatments were applied to eight points on the affected side of the face three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of therapeutic ultrasound, including its use in multi-component interventions, with other non-surgical treatments like Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: One low-quality trial found that therapeutic ultrasound plus splint was less effective than LLLT plus splint for short-term overall improvement in CTS symptoms, though the results were not statistically significant. The study noted methodological limitations, including lack of blinding and unclear allocation concealment.
population_specificity: People with mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
study_duration: Three months post-treatment (for the comparison involving LLLT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of locally applied low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in improving symptoms of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved total symptom scores (TSS) by 39% at 2 weeks and 46.34% at 4 weeks, with a large effect size (ηp² = 0.63), and the therapeutic effect lasted for a mean of 5 months.
population_specificity: Fifteen adult patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
effective_dosage: 830-nm Ga-Al-As laser, continuous-wave mode, 30 mW power output, 1 J energy dose, 33 sec per point (6 points per sinus), 3 times per week for 10 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of Low-Level Laser Therapy in a multimodal therapeutic program for managing pain and function in patients with osteoarthritis of the knee or hip.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Low-Level Laser Therapy, along with other modalities, may positively influence pain, function, mobility, and quality of life in patients with lower limb osteoarthritis, though specific efficacy data is not detailed.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly persons with osteoarthritis of the knee or hip.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) increases nitric oxide (NO) levels in venous blood at the treatment site.
results_summary: LLLT significantly increased NO levels in venous blood, with peak levels occurring 5 minutes into treatment and gradually declining afterward. The treatment effect was statistically significant compared to sham treatment.
population_specificity: Fifteen healthy subjects
study_duration: Treatment duration not specified; blood samples were taken up to 30 minutes post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in managing pain, swelling, and trismus after third-molar surgery compared to ozone therapy and a control group.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced postoperative pain, trismus, and swelling compared to the control group, and improved patients' quality of life. It outperformed ozone therapy in reducing trismus and swelling.
population_specificity: 60 patients (28 female, 32 male) aged 18-25 with asymptomatic impacted mandibular third molars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) using green 532 nm diodes as a stand-alone treatment for improving cellulite appearance in thighs and buttocks, without requiring massage or mechanical manipulation.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved cellulite appearance, with 55.88% of treated subjects achieving a one-stage or greater improvement on the Nurnberger-Muller scale, compared to 8.82% in the sham group. Treated subjects also showed significant reductions in thigh circumference, body weight, BMI, and cellulite-affected body surface area, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Post-adolescent women with cellulite in the thighs and buttocks.
effective_dosage: Three weekly treatment sessions, 15 minutes per side (30 minutes total per session), over 2 weeks.
study_duration: 2-week treatment phase with a 6-week follow-up evaluation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of 810-nm continuous wave low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain caused by orthodontic elastomeric separators.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain perception in the first 3 days after orthodontic separation, with notable differences between laser and placebo groups at 6, 24, 30 hours, and day 3. Pain was highest at 6 and 30 hours post-separation, with no gender differences but more pain recorded in the mandible and older age groups at specific time points.
population_specificity: 37 orthodontic patients (12 male, 25 female, aged 11-32 years).
effective_dosage: 10 doses (2 J/cm², 100 mW, 20 s per dose) administered twice (after separator placement and 24 hours later).
study_duration: 7 days (pain monitored up to day 7, intervention administered twice within 24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence-based nonpharmacological interventions, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for the conservative management of knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT is moderately supported in the literature as an indicated management strategy for knee OA, though additional research is needed to determine its effectiveness compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Middle-aged athletic and recreationally active individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: To systematically review studies investigating the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain levels in individuals with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
results_summary: Most studies (13 out of 14) reported a reduction in pain levels, with 9 showing effects only in the experimental group and 4 in both experimental and placebo groups. However, variability in laser parameters calls for cautious interpretation.
population_specificity: Individuals with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
effective_dosage: Energy density ranged from 0.9 to 105 J/cm²; power density ranged from 9.8 to 500 mW; sessions varied from 1 to 20, with frequencies from daily for 10 days to once weekly for 4 weeks.
study_duration: Varied from single sessions to 20 sessions over 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in managing pain and improving mouth opening in patients with myogenic temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in mouth opening and reduction in pain symptoms in the LLLT group, but no significant improvement in the placebo group. However, between-group comparisons showed no significant differences in pain intensity or mouth opening at any evaluation time point.
population_specificity: 20 patients with myogenic temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).
effective_dosage: Pulsed 810-nm low-level laser (average power 50 mW, peak power 80 W, 1,500 Hz, 120 s, 6 J, and 3.4 J/cm² per point), applied three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on skeletal muscle fatigue in elderly women.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly increased the number of repetitions during knee flexion-extension exercise but did not delay electromyographic fatigue. No difference was observed in the slope coefficient of median frequency between active and placebo LLLT groups.
population_specificity: Elderly women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of combining piroxicam with low-level laser therapy versus using either treatment alone for temporomandibular joint arthralgia.
results_summary: All treatment groups showed significant improvement in pain scores, but the combination therapy was not more effective than single therapies. Piroxicam alone was more effective in reducing joint and muscle pain at the 30-day follow-up.
population_specificity: 32 patients with temporomandibular joint arthralgia.
effective_dosage: Infrared laser (830 nm, 100 mW, 28 s, 100 J cm(-2)) applied to 10 points per side; piroxicam 20 mg daily.
study_duration: 10 days of piroxicam with four laser sessions.

study_goal: To analyze the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain perception after orthodontic separator placement and compare it with control and placebo groups using a frequent irradiation protocol.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain scores compared to the control group up to 1 day, while the placebo (LED) group showed no significant difference from the control after the first 6 hours. Frequent LLLT maintained reduced pain perception throughout the week.
population_specificity: 88 patients undergoing orthodontic separator placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of GaAlAs laser light in reducing pain induced by post-adjustment orthodontic final archwire and to compare pain gradients between conventional and self-ligating brackets.
results_summary: The study found that Low-Level Laser Therapy significantly reduced pain up to 7 days post-application, regardless of bracket type, with statistical significance (p<0.00001). Pain peaked 24 hours after archwire activation but was consistently alleviated by laser treatment.
population_specificity: 60 orthodontic patients (30 with conventional brackets, 30 with self-ligating brackets) undergoing final-stage orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 830 nm, 100mW laser for 22 sec (2.2 J, 80 J/cm²) on vestibular and palatal surfaces per arch.
study_duration: Pain evaluated up to 7 days post-application.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy when combined with orthoses therapy and home orientations in improving symptoms and hand function in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not provide specific results regarding the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy. The outcomes were to be assessed using pain scales, sensibility tests, and questionnaires, but no findings are reported.
population_specificity: Patients older than 18 years with a clinical diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome, excluding comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in treating lymphedema after breast cancer, focusing on its effects on limb volume reduction and potential risks of recurrence or metastasis.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT reduced limb volume compared to other treatments, but no studies assessed the risk of metastasis or relapse. The efficacy of LLLT relative to complex physical therapy remains unclear due to lack of comparative studies.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients with secondary lymphedema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of low-level laser therapy in managing hair loss, particularly for pattern hair loss and alopecia areata.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that low-level laser therapy is being explored as a novel method for hair growth induction, but it does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes from the study.
population_specificity: Patients presenting to dermatologists with pattern hair loss or alopecia areata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on tender points in patients with fibromyalgia, correlating it with quality of life and sleep.
results_summary: The study proposed to assess LLLT's impact on pain (primary outcome) using visual analog scales, McGill Pain Questionnaire, and pressure algometry, as well as secondary outcomes like quality of life and sleep using standardized questionnaires and polysomnography. Results were not provided in the abstract, but the study design suggests a rigorous evaluation of LLLT's effects.
population_specificity: 120 patients with fibromyalgia treated at a health center in Sao Paulo, Brazil.
effective_dosage: 6 J per tender point, three times per week for four weeks (12 sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on patient-reported measures of oral mucositis (OM) and quality of life (QOL) in head and neck cancer patients undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved patient-reported OM symptoms and QOL, reduced severe OM incidence, and decreased the need for opioid analgesics and parenteral nutrition compared to placebo. The effects were statistically significant (p < 0.05 for QOL, p < 0.001 for OM).
population_specificity: 220 head and neck cancer patients receiving chemoradiotherapy (three weekly cisplatin + 66 Gray radiation over 6.5 weeks).
effective_dosage: 3.0 J per point, total dose/session = 36-40 J, spot size 1 cm², irradiation time/point 125 s, before each radiation session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for treating orofacial pain by evaluating study methodologies and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence that LLLT is more effective than placebo, sham laser, or other active treatments, with mixed results across high-quality trials. Quality of trials was not significantly associated with neutral outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with orofacial pain (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for treating temporomandibular disorders (TMD) by reviewing randomized placebo-controlled trials.
results_summary: The review found mixed and inconclusive results regarding LLLT's efficacy for TMD, with no clear correlation to laser beam features, application frequency, or duration. LLLT appeared more effective for TMJ disorders than masticatory muscle disorders, but methodological differences prevented definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Human subjects with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied across studies in wavelength, frequency, output, and dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) at 830 nm wavelength in reducing pain caused by orthodontic separators.
results_summary: The intervention group (LLLT) showed significantly lower mean pain scores and a higher incidence of complete pain absence compared to the placebo group. The study concluded that LLLT effectively controlled pain from orthodontic separators.
population_specificity: 60 orthodontic patients aged 12-26 years (mean ~17.5 years).
effective_dosage: 2 J/cm² at the radicular apex and three spots of 1 J/cm² along the buccal surface.
study_duration: Single irradiation session immediately after separator placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of low-level laser therapy on intra-articular temporomandibular disorders (IA-TMD) by comparing symptom severity before, during, and after treatment at different energy doses.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in mandibular range of motion and reduction in painful symptoms for groups receiving effective laser treatment (52.5 J/cm² and 105.0 J/cm²), with no such improvements in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 45 subjects with intra-articular temporomandibular disorders (IA-TMD), divided into three groups of 15 each.
effective_dosage: 52.5 J/cm² (G-I) and 105.0 J/cm² (G-II), applied twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain and improving function in patients with meniscal pathology who did not undergo surgery.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved pain and Lysholm scores compared to placebo, with sustained benefits observed at 6 months and 1 year. A small subset (12.5%) did not respond to treatment.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with meniscal pathology (tiny grade 3 attenuation or intrasubstance tears approaching the articular surface).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as a management option for cancer-related lymphedema symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT, along with other therapies like complex physical therapy and pharmacotherapy, can help manage symptoms of lymphedema but does not cure the condition. The evidence for LLLT's efficacy was included among various treatment options reviewed.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer-related lymphedema, primarily breast cancer survivors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of conservative interventions, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for midportion Achilles tendinopathy (AT) based on available literature and expert clinical reasoning.
results_summary: The study found moderate evidence supporting the efficacy of LLLT for midportion AT, though it was considered inferior to eccentric loading exercises. The evidence was derived from multiple studies evaluated using the PEDro scale.
population_specificity: Patients with midportion Achilles tendinopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in managing orthodontic pain through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that LLLT reduced the risk of pain incidence by 24% and accelerated the timing of the "most painful day." However, methodological limitations and bias in included trials limited the evidence for LLLT's effectiveness in delaying pain onset or reducing intensity.
population_specificity: 641 patients from six countries undergoing orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and low-intensity pulsed ultrasound in accelerating orthodontic tooth movement and improving tissue quality.
results_summary: The study suggests that LLLT and low-intensity pulsed ultrasound show promise in reducing orthodontic treatment time and enhancing tissue quality, based on a review of previous literature.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on masticatory performance, pressure pain threshold, and pain intensity in patients with myofascial pain.
results_summary: LLLT improved masticatory performance and increased pressure pain threshold in the laser group, with both groups showing reduced pain intensity by the end of treatment. The effects were statistically significant for the laser group but not for the placebo group.
population_specificity: Patients with myofascial pain according to Research Diagnostic Criteria/temporomandibular dysfunction (n=21).
effective_dosage: Two times per week for 4 weeks (specific laser parameters not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically assess the efficacy of electrophysical therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, in treating diabetic foot ulcers through randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that Low-Level Laser Therapy showed significant benefits in healing diabetic foot ulcers compared to control or sham groups, though the analysis was limited to only two RCTs. Pooled results for electrophysical therapies overall indicated statistical significance in favor of treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of three different energy doses of LLLT on pain and functional outcomes in patients with acute low back pain and radiculopathy.
results_summary: All three LLLT doses significantly reduced pain (VAS scores) with no differences between groups, but the highest dose (4 J per point) showed superior functional improvements in daily living and lumbar mobility.
population_specificity: 66 patients with acute low back pain and radiculopathy.
effective_dosage: 0.1 J, 1 J, and 4 J per point, administered 5 times weekly for 10 treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on reducing gingival inflammation in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) and periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced gingival inflammation in patients with DM and periodontitis, with no significant difference between DM patients and the control group after therapy. The therapy was effective as an adjunct to standard periodontal treatment.
population_specificity: 300 patients divided into three groups: Group 1 (type 1 DM and periodontitis), Group 2 (type 2 DM and periodontitis), and Group 3 (periodontitis only, control group).
effective_dosage: GaAlAs LLLT (670 nm, 5 mW, 14 min/day) for five consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different low-level laser therapy (LLLT) wavelengths as an adjunct to standard therapy in improving trismus and oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) in acute pericoronitis patients.
results_summary: The study found that 1064-nm Nd:YAG and 808-nm diode lasers significantly improved trismus and OHRQoL at 24 hours compared to the 660-nm diode and control groups, though no differences were observed by day 7. The results suggest these lasers are effective for short-term symptom relief in acute pericoronitis.
population_specificity: 80 patients with acute pericoronitis.
effective_dosage: Nd:YAG (8 J/cm², 0.25 W, 10 Hz, 10 sec), 808-nm diode (8 J/cm², 0.25 W, continuous mode, 10 sec), 660-nm diode (8 J/cm², 0.04 W, continuous mode, 60 sec).
study_duration: Single application with follow-up at 24 hours and 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in managing breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
results_summary: The study found moderate to strong evidence supporting LLLT's effectiveness in reducing limb volume in BCRL patients, with five studies graded at evidence level II. A dose of 1-2 J/cm² per point applied to fibrotic areas was effective.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients with lymphedema (230 patients across eight studies).
effective_dosage: 1-2 J/cm² per point applied to several points covering the fibrotic area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on wound healing and pain levels after premolar extraction in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT did not significantly reduce pain intensity or improve wound healing compared to the placebo group. Both groups showed similar wound healing progression, and pain reduction differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adolescents undergoing surgical removal of premolars.
effective_dosage: 5.1 J (60 J/cm²) of energy density at three intraoral points, applied immediately and at 48 and 72 hours post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-level laser therapy on postoperative pain in patients undergoing third molar surgery.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in pain levels in the laser-treated group compared to the control group, but no significant difference in pain duration between the two groups.
population_specificity: 100 patients undergoing surgical removal of one mandibular third molar.
effective_dosage: 100 mW in continuous mode with sweeping motion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could alleviate pain and promote healing in patients undergoing micro-marsupialization for oral ranulas and selected mucoceles.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT led to clinical healing in all treated cases with no recurrence observed during an 11-month follow-up, suggesting it is an effective alternative for pain reduction and healing.
population_specificity: Eleven patients with oral ranulas and selected mucoceles.
effective_dosage: 660-nm continuous wave laser at 100 mW, irradiance of 3.53 W/cm², applied immediately post-procedure and at 24, 48, and 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and CO(2) laser therapy in treating oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: Both LLLT and CO(2) laser therapy improved lesion size, pain, and clinical response scores, with LLLT showing 100% partial to complete improvement compared to 85% for CO(2) laser after 3 months. LLLT demonstrated better results as an alternative or additional therapy for OLP.
population_specificity: 28 patients with 57 lesions of oral lichen planus.
study_duration: 3 months (with follow-up assessments at 2 weeks, 1, 2, and 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain, swelling, and trismus following surgical removal of impacted lower third molars.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT improved interincisal opening and significantly reduced trismus, swelling, and pain intensity on the first and seventh postoperative days compared to the control group. However, the abstract notes mixed results in prior studies, with some reporting positive effects and others finding no benefit.
population_specificity: Thirty patients undergoing surgical removal of impacted lower third molars, randomized into LLLT (n=15) and control (n=15) groups.
effective_dosage: 980-nm diode laser at 300 mW (0.3 W) for 180 s (60 s × 3) per session, delivering 54 J per session.
study_duration: LLLT was administered immediately after surgery and at 24 hours post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on joint pain by analyzing clinical trials that met specific methodological criteria.
results_summary: The review found that LLLT reduced joint pain, with a mean weighted difference in pain reduction of 13.96 mm on the VAS. When restricted to trials using recommended energy doses, the effect sizes increased to 19.88 mm and 21.05 mm, indicating more reliable pain relief.
population_specificity: Patients with joint pain (1014 participants across 22 trials).
effective_dosage: Energy doses within the range suggested by Bjordal et al. (2003) and WALT recommendations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces post-adjustment orthodontic pain by evaluating changes in prostaglandin-E(2) (PGE(2)) levels and pain perception via visual analogue scale (VAS).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain intensity and PGE(2) levels 24 hours after application compared to the control group, though no differences were observed at earlier time points. The study concluded that LLLT is effective in reducing orthodontic post-adjustment pain.
population_specificity: 19 patients (11 females, 8 males; mean age 13.9 years) undergoing orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: λ820 nm; continuous wave; output power: 50 mW; focal spot: 0.0314 cm²; exposure duration: 5 sec; power density: 1.59 W/cm²; energy dose: 0.25 J; energy density: 7.96 J/cm² per shot.
study_duration: Single session with follow-up measurements at 1 and 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if prophylactic low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could prevent and treat oral mucositis (OM) induced by concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced the incidence of severe OM, associated pain, dysphagia, and opioid analgesic use compared to the placebo group, with statistically significant results (p<0.0001).
population_specificity: 221 head and neck cancer patients scheduled for CCRT.
effective_dosage: HeNe laser (λ=632.8 nm, power-density=24 mW, dosage=3.0 J/point, total dosage/session=36-40 J, spot-size=1cm²), 5 sessions/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating oral candidiasis in HIV-infected patients.
results_summary: LLLT alone showed no reduction in Candida spp., while aPDT (combining LLLT with methylene blue) eradicated 100% of fungal colonies with no recurrence up to 30 days post-treatment. Fluconazole was effective but did not prevent short-term recurrence.
population_specificity: HIV-infected patients with oral candidiasis
effective_dosage: LLLT: 660 nm wavelength, 30 mW power, 7.5 J/cm² fluence, 10 sec per point; aPDT: same laser parameters with methylene blue 450 μg/mL, 1 min pre-irradiation
study_duration: Single irradiation session for LLLT and aPDT; fluconazole administered for 14 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could effectively accelerate orthodontic tooth movement compared to other interventions.
results_summary: The study concluded that LLLT was unable to accelerate orthodontic tooth movement, based on the included trials. No significant adverse effects were reported, but efficacy was not demonstrated.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the existing literature on Low-Level Laser Therapy as a complementary treatment for osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Low-Level Laser Therapy, only mentioning it as one of several alternative treatments reviewed for osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (general population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in improving thyroid function, reducing autoimmunity, and enhancing thyroid echogenicity in patients with chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (CAT)-induced hypothyroidism.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced the required levothyroxine dose, lowered thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPOAb), and increased thyroid echogenicity compared to placebo, but showed no effect on thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAb).
population_specificity: 43 patients with CAT-induced hypothyroidism on levothyroxine therapy.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of LLLT (830 nm, 50 mW, fluence of 707 J/cm²).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy for pain relief in the perineum following episiotomy during childbirth.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in perineal pain relief between the groups treated with red or infrared laser and the control group, indicating low-level laser therapy did not reduce pain intensity.
population_specificity: 114 women who underwent right mediolateral episiotomies during vaginal birth and reported pain ≥ 3 on a numeric scale (0-10).
effective_dosage: Single session of laser therapy applied at three points on the episiotomy, using wavelengths of 660 nm (red laser) and 780 nm (infrared laser).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to eccentric exercises improves outcomes in Achilles' tendinopathy compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in VISA-A scores between LLLT and placebo groups at 12 weeks, with placebo showing better results at 4 weeks. No significant differences were observed at other time points.
population_specificity: Adults with midportion Achilles' tendinopathy (mean age ~46 years).
effective_dosage: 3J per point, 3 times per week for 4 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks (eccentric exercises for 3 months; LLLT for first 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of COX-2 during tissue repair induced by low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in humans and experimental models.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that COX-2 expression is implicated in inflammation during tissue repair induced by LLLT, with varying results depending on experimental protocols and dosages. The role of COX-2 in LLLT-induced tissue repair remains an area needing further investigation.
population_specificity: Humans and experimental models (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of adding low-level laser therapy (830 nm) to ultrasound and exercise for managing shoulder tendonitis.
results_summary: Both treatment groups (laser + ultrasound + exercise vs. ultrasound + exercise alone) showed significant improvements in pain and function, but the laser group demonstrated superior muscle strength improvement. The study suggests LLLT may enhance muscle recovery in shoulder tendonitis.
population_specificity: 42 subjects with shoulder tendonitis (21 in each group).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions over one month (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 1 month of treatment, with follow-up at 2 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for preventing and treating oral mucositis caused by cancer therapy.
results_summary: Meta-analysis of 33 studies showed LLLT significantly reduced the risk, duration, and severity of oral mucositis, with no reported adverse effects. Pain relief was also observed, and both red and infrared wavelengths were similarly effective.
population_specificity: Cancer therapy patients with or at risk of oral mucositis.
effective_dosage: 10-100 mW diode output, 2-3 J/cm² for prophylaxis, 4 J/cm² (maximum) for therapy, applied daily or every other day.
study_duration: Until resolution of lesions, with a minimum of three sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the scientific evidence on the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant effect of LLLT on pain reduction in TMD patients compared to placebo. Secondary outcomes showed minor improvements in mandibular function, but these were not clinically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic temporomandibular disorders (TMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for noninvasive body slimming and determine if the observed circumferential reduction was due to fluid or fat relocation.
results_summary: The study found a significant mean circumferential reduction of 3.27 inches in treated areas (waist, hips, thighs) and 5.17 inches across all measured regions, indicating that the effect was systemic and not limited to treated areas. The results suggest the reduction was not attributable to fluid or fat relocation.
population_specificity: 689 participants receiving LLLT for body contouring (no pre-selection criteria mentioned).
effective_dosage: Six LLLT treatments over 2 weeks (specific laser parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of therapeutic ultrasound, including its use in multi-component interventions, with other non-surgical treatments like Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study found limited evidence suggesting LLLT plus splint may be more effective than therapeutic ultrasound plus splint for short-term improvement in CTS symptoms, though results were not statistically significant. Overall, the evidence for LLLT's superiority over other non-surgical interventions was inconclusive due to low-quality trials and methodological limitations.
population_specificity: People with mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (443 participants across 11 studies).
study_duration: Varied across studies; one trial measured outcomes at three months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) enhances the release of growth factors (bFGF, IGF-I, IGFBP3) and promotes proliferation and viability in osteoblasts derived from human mesenchymal stem cells.
results_summary: LLLT increased osteoblast proliferation, viability, and the release of bFGF, IGF-I, and IGFBP3 compared to non-irradiated controls. The double-dose group showed higher bFGF and IGF-I but lower IGFBP3 levels than the single-dose group.
population_specificity: Human mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) differentiated into osteoblasts.
effective_dosage: 685 nm, 25 mW, 14.3 mW/cm², 140 sec, 2 J/cm² (single dose or two consecutive days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as a nonsurgical treatment for neurosensory deficits following lower third molar surgery.
results_summary: LLLT was identified as one of two nonsurgical treatments that significantly improved sensation in more than 50% of subjects. However, complete recovery was uncommon across all treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with neurosensory deficits (lingual or inferior alveolar nerve) after lower third molar surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) improves outcomes in chronic periodontitis compared to SRP alone.
results_summary: SRP+LLLT showed greater short-term reductions in probing pocket depth (PPD) at 5 weeks and 3 months, but not at 6 months, and significantly improved radiographic bone density from baseline to 12 months. No significant effect was observed on interleukin (IL)-1β levels or gingival/plaque indices.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients with chronic periodontitis and probing pocket depths of 4-6 mm involving at least three teeth per quadrant.
effective_dosage: 830 nm, 100 mW, 3 J per point, 3 J/cm² (10 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of specific LLLT parameters on biofilms formed by Streptococcus mutans, Candida albicans, or both species.
results_summary: LLLT reduced cell viability and biofilm growth, with S. mutans showing resistance when associated with C. albicans. C. albicans biofilm growth decreased dose-dependently in dual-species biofilms, and hyphae formation was reduced.
population_specificity: Biofilms of Streptococcus mutans, Candida albicans, or both species.
effective_dosage: 5, 10, or 20 J/cm² from a near-infrared InGaAsP diode laser (780 ± 3 nm, 0.04 W).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could improve visual acuity in adolescent and adult patients with amblyopia caused by ametropia or strabismus.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved visual acuity in ~90% of treated eyes, with over 50% of eyes gaining three or more lines on the Snellen chart. The treatment effect persisted for at least 6 months, and M-VEP amplitude increased while latency decreased.
population_specificity: 178 patients (mean age 46.8 years) with amblyopia caused by ametropia (110 eyes) or strabismus (121 eyes).
effective_dosage: 780 nm laser, 7.5 mW average power, 3 mm² spot area, 0.77 J/cm² total dose, administered 3.5 times on average.
study_duration: Each session lasted 30 seconds, repeated over an unspecified period (mean 3.5 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as part of a broader update to Dutch physiotherapy guidelines for Hip and Knee Osteoarthritis (HKOA).
results_summary: The study concluded that Low-Level Laser Therapy could not be recommended for the treatment of HKOA, as it lacked sufficient evidence to support its efficacy. It was neither explicitly discouraged nor endorsed, indicating inconclusive findings.
population_specificity: Patients with Hip and Knee Osteoarthritis (HKOA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy combined with exercises on pain, functionality, range of motion, muscular strength, and quality of life in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: The laser group showed significant improvements in pain, range of motion, functionality, and activity compared to baseline, while the placebo group did not. Significant differences between groups were found only in activity levels.
population_specificity: 40 participants with knee osteoarthritis (grades 2-4), aged 50-75 years, both genders.
effective_dosage: Low-level laser therapy dose of 3 J (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Laser therapy for 3 weeks, followed by exercises for a total of 11 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) combined with conventional physiotherapy provides additive benefits for pain reduction and functional improvement in patients with rotator cuff tendinitis compared to physiotherapy alone.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT combined with conventional physiotherapy significantly improved pain control and functional ability compared to physiotherapy alone, but no additional benefits were observed in shoulder joint range of motion.
population_specificity: 50 patients with shoulder pain and rotator cuff disorders referred to a Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Clinic.
effective_dosage: 4 J/cm² at each point over a maximum of ten painful points in the shoulder region, totaling 5 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current noninvasive body-contouring modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, and discuss their clinical effects, patient selection, and applicability.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Low-Level Laser Therapy as one of the existing noninvasive lipolysis technologies but does not provide specific findings on its effectiveness or outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and Pulsed Magnetic Field (PMF) in rehabilitating patients with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: LLLT showed significant reduction in day and night pain at all treatment stages and six months post-treatment, while PMF only showed significant pain reduction after the second series. Both therapies reduced pain intensity, but LLLT demonstrated more consistent and lasting improvements.
population_specificity: 38 patients with idiopathic carpal tunnel syndrome confirmed by electroneurographic examination.
study_duration: Two series of 10 sessions each, with a two-week break between series.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on healing and relapse intervals in patients with recurrent labial herpes simplex infections.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant effects on both initial healing and the length of recurrence periods, with no observed side effects. Patients receiving LLLT experienced improved outcomes compared to conventional therapy.
population_specificity: 232 patients with herpes simplex type 1 virus symptoms in the initial study, and 322 patients in a consecutive 5-year follow-up study.
effective_dosage: 670-nm laser irradiation, 40 mW, 1.6 J, 2.04 J/cm², 51 mW/cm² per blister in the prodromal stage; 4.8 J in the crust and secondarily infected stages; plus 1.2 J at the C2-C3 vertebrae.
study_duration: Daily monitoring during the first week for healing, monthly for 1 year for recurrence, and 5 years for the consecutive study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether endurance training combined with Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could improve muscle performance, specifically by reducing fatigue and increasing total work in knee extensor muscles compared to training alone.
results_summary: The study found that endurance training with LLLT significantly reduced fatigue in both dominant and nondominant lower limbs, while training alone increased total work in both limbs. The control group showed no improvements in fatigue or total work.
population_specificity: 45 clinically healthy women aged 21 ± 1.78 years.
effective_dosage: 808 nm infrared laser, six 60-mW diodes, 0.6 J per diode, total 18 J per limb, applied immediately after each training session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of low-level laser therapy in preventing and treating mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: Group 1 (higher dosage) showed delayed onset and lower severity of mucositis compared to Group 2 (lower dosage), with significant differences in mucositis grades and pain levels. Low-level laser therapy was effective in controlling mucositis intensity and pain.
population_specificity: 70 patients with malignant neoplasms in the oral cavity or oropharynx.
study_duration: From the first day of radiotherapy until mucositis assessment (up to 26 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on perineal pain and episiotomy healing in postpartum women.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT did not significantly accelerate episiotomy healing compared to the control group. While the experimental group showed a reduction in perineal pain scores after some sessions, there was no statistical difference between the groups at any time point.
population_specificity: Fifty-two postpartum women who had mediolateral episiotomies during their first normal delivery.
effective_dosage: Diode laser with 660 nm wavelength, 0.04 cm² spot size, 3.8 J/cm² energy density, 15 mW radiant power, 10s per point (0.15 J per point, 0.45 J per session), administered in three sessions.
study_duration: Three sessions: up to 2 hrs postpartum, between 20-24 hrs postpartum, and between 40-48 hrs postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of red and infrared low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on delaying skeletal muscle fatigue and enhancing muscle performance.
results_summary: Both red and infrared LLLT significantly increased mean peak force (12.14% and 14.49%, respectively) and mean average force (13.09% and 13.24%, respectively) compared to placebo, with no significant differences between the two wavelengths.
population_specificity: Ten healthy male volunteers.
effective_dosage: 660 or 830 nm, 50 mW, 17.85 W/cm², 100 s irradiation per point, 5 J, 1,785 J/cm² at each point, total 20 J per muscle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of laser surgery with biostimulation (LLLT) to conventional surgery in treating bisphosphonate-induced avascular bone necrosis.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in treatment outcomes between laser surgery and conventional surgery, though laser surgery was noted as a beneficial alternative. Patients with stage II osteonecrosis had significantly better outcomes than those with stage I.
population_specificity: 20 patients with lung, prostate, or breast cancer under intravenous bisphosphonate treatment who developed mandibular or maxillary avascular necrosis.
effective_dosage: Nd:YAG laser (0.25 W, 10 Hz, 6.25 J/cm² energy density) applied for 1 minute from 4 cm distance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the quality of clinical practice guidelines regarding physiotherapy interventions, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy was addressed in one or two of the six recommended guidelines, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy or safety results for this intervention. The guidelines generally lacked detail on mode of delivery, intensity, frequency, and duration.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
